text: Brian Robinson wrote this article saying that funding the federal health care law without a tax hike is gonna require Georgia to cut almost a quarter of its annual budget. Can you believe that? A quarter.

A quarter of the state budget? That sounds like an astronomical amount. I mean, health care is expensive, but to necessitate cuts that deep just to fund a federal law without new taxes, for Medicaid and everything...
I'd have to see the breakdown of those numbers.

It's huge, right? Think about the impact on state services, education, infrastructure. If they have to slash that much from the annual budget, it's gonna affect everyone. It's a massive consequence of this health care law.

I agree the impact would be massive. I'm just questioning if the premise is correct, that it must come out of the existing state budget in such a drastic way, especially for a federal health care initiative. There might be other funding mechanisms or calculations I'm not aware of.
